Section 4.1 · Feedback

Three Forms of Agentic Feedback

Figure 5: Three Forms of Agentic Feedback Mechanisms

  • Reflective Feedback: Inference-time reflection enables real-time self-critique and revision during reasoning
  • Parametric Adaptation: Offline adaptation consolidates feedback into model parameters for long-term improvement
  • Validator-Driven Feedback: Outcome-based feedback relies on validator signals (success or failure) to refine behavior through retry

4.1.1 Reflective Feedback

Reflective feedback methods improve model reliability by modifying the reasoning process during inference, without updating model parameters. These approaches expose intermediate reasoning outputs, such as chains of thought or partial solutions, and introduce additional assessment steps that directly influence how the model continues its generation.

Early self-critique and rationale-refinement methods implement reflection through an explicit generate-critique-revise loop. A model first produces an answer together with its reasoning. The same model, or a separately prompted critic role, then analyzes this output to identify logical errors, unsupported assumptions, or missing steps.

Analysis & Explanation

Feedback Trade-offs

When to Use Each
  • Reflective: Best for complex reasoning tasks where self-correction is valuable
  • Parametric: Best when you have training data and want persistent improvements
  • Validator: Best for tasks with clear success/failure criteria (code, math)
